data.formatted_address: Lintong District, Xi'An, Shaanxi, China, 710612
data.name: Emperor Qinshihuang's Mausoleum Site Museum

reviews.text:
One of the most magnificent places I have been to/things I have seen. It will only get better over time as well, as they are always finding/restoring more and more soldiers over time. Despite the crowds which can be overwhelming at times, it is still very worth the trip if traveling to or around Xi'an. It seems worth it to pay for a tour guide or at least do what we did, and get the audio guide. So much great information about the history and restoration efforts.

One thing I have not seen people mention is the pomegranate juice stalls outside the grounds. We went last October which happened to be pomegranate season. So I cannot speak to the quality the rest of the year, but at that time, it was so fresh, possibly the best juice I have ever had. They generally have some juice bottles already sitting out, but you'll want them to freshly squeeze you a new one. So good we had to buy another round. I still think about how good that juice was even months later.

A really good experience. The museum is well organised and despite 64000 tickets being issued daily, it was easy to get to the displays in the 3 pits. Plenty to do outside the museum too with lots of different food and drink shops. Plenty for souvenir hunters too, don't be afraid to haggle. I got quite a few souvenirs for half of the price they were asking! All together a great day out. I was lucky and got a ticket the day I visited, but I recommend you apply and buy your ticket at least 3 days before you go.

This is without a doubt one of the most amazing and impressive archeological sights in the world! It's an absolute must see for anyone who is interested in the ancient world. Make sure you go to both the museum with the terracotta warriors and also the one with the bronzes which is up the hill a bit!

Emperor Qinshihuang's Mausoleum is an awe-inspiring testament to ancient Chinese ingenuity and craftsmanship. The site, home to the famous Terracotta Army, offers a fascinating glimpse into the past with its life-sized statues that were meticulously crafted to guard the emperor in the afterlife. The scale and detail of the figures are breathtaking, and the surrounding museum provides valuable historical context. The mausoleum complex itself is well-preserved, and the guided tours are informative and engaging. This UNESCO World Heritage site is a must-visit for history enthusiasts and anyone interested in the grandeur of ancient China.

Ended up taking a 120rmb private car ride from the train station to the site as we could not find the free shuttle bus. Do note that u can easily get Terracotta tickets on WeChat by just inputting any China phone number! Although it was a rainy day, it did not turn away the crowd. Pit 1 was definitely the most spectacular sight! Glad to have witnessed this massive inspirational motivation by the Qin Emperor for his afterlife.

data.formatted_address: 7W5W+QRJ, Beilin, Xi'An, Shaanxi, China, 710007
data.name: Bell Tower of Xi'an

reviews.text:
Great view both day and night, sunny day or snowy day.. view at night is better with all the lights lighting up the sky.

When I visited Xi'an, the hotel was just a short walk from it, so I always got to see it. It's a hotspot for tourists, so expect to see big crowds at times also with girls in ancient costumes.

One of the best attraction in Xi’an, like a centre piece placed right in the middle of the city inside the 1000yrs old citywall. Around Bell Towers are the main attractions of Xian and also shopping malls and food streets. The Bell Tower itself looked very attractive and well maintained.

The entrance was a little confusing though. The underground signs say Exit 7, but actually the more accurate location should be the exit from metro Line 2 escalator (as one comes up from metro platform to the roundabout exits).

The ticketing area is an automated self-service one but requires a local ID so I had to ask the staff for help and she used her ID to bypass the system for me. Later realised I could have just bought it on the CTrip app too, since the automated system uses Ctrip's system too. The prices are the same. Entrance fees are CNY30 per tower or CNY50 for both.

The entrance to the Bell Tower is just beside the ticketing area. Followed the path through security checks and finally made it to the Bell Tower, which sits in the middle of the city in a roundabout.

The Bell Tower was critical in the past to indicate time. Hence, there are a number of such similar towers in other cities such as Beijing. Today, it's more of a historic presence and showcase of ancient finess in architecture and construction. The architectural structure, the drawings within, the construction of such a huge bell.

The Bell Tower of Xi'an built in 1384 during the early ming dinasty, is a symbol of the city of xian. On October 10, 1939, the Xi'an Bell Tower was bombed by Japanese planes and was seriously damaged. Has a jingyun bell outside the building. Inside the building like a museum, we can see the history and old things such as the vase. From the bell tower you can see from the top view of road
Beautiful tower that's really nice to visit at night

data.formatted_address: 7W7Q+7JF, Hua Jue Xiang, Lian Hu Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710001
data.name: Great Mosque of Xi'an

reviews.text: This is definitely a gem in Xian. It is said that this is the only mosque built in the Chinese architectural style but with two cultural arts, texts, and crafts. While most Chinese buildings are facing south, this mosque faces west for Mecca. This mosque is situated at the Muslim Quarter near the Drum Tower, where tourists come here for the two towers, food, and snacks. I think if you are in the area, it is absolutely worth RMB 25 for a visit to this mosque.

The Great Mosque of Xi'an, built in 742 AD during the Tang Dynasty, is one of China's oldest mosques. It has been expanded and renovated over the centuries, especially during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) and the Qing Dynasty (1644-1912).

- As a Muslim, you don't have to get a ticket to pray in the mosque.

By far one of the coolest mosques we've been to, and one of our favorite places in Xi'an. The mosque is stunning and blends in Chinese architecture and Islamic forms/buildings in beautiful and fascinating ways. There are many buildings and courtyards in the complex, each packed with details that'll make you excited to be there.

Walking through the market on the way out was lots of fun, with lots of food and souvenir options.
One of the oldest Mosques 🕌 in China , Stunning architecture nicely maintained, Such a peaceful place in middle of the city

UNESCO World Heritage Site
Visited Oct 2015

The Great Mosque of Xi'an is one of the largest premodern mosques in China. Although the mosque was first built in the year 742 AD during the Tang dynasty, its current form was largely constructed in 1384 AD during Emperor Hongwu's reign of the Ming dynasty.

An active place of worship within Xi'an Muslim Quarter, It now houses more than twenty buildings in its five courtyards, and covers 1.23 hectares

data.formatted_address: China, Shan Xi Sheng, Xi An Shi, Yan Ta Qu, Ci En Lu, 慈恩路大慈恩寺内 邮政编码: 710063
data.name: Bell Tower

reviews.text: Giant Wild Goose Pagoda or Big Wild Goose Pagoda (Chinese: 大雁塔; pinyin: Dàyàn tǎ, literally "swan goose pagoda"), is a Buddhist pagoda located in southern Xi'An, Shaanxi, China. It was built in 652 during the Tang dynasty and originally had five stories and was bild to accommodate the original relics brought by the monk who went to India and brought back the teaching of Siddhartha Gautama and it's composed of small temples office and residential buildings... The structure was rebuilt in 704 during the reign of Empress Wu Zetian and its exterior brick facade was renovated during the Ming Dynasty.
The bell and drum towers are at the entrance to the Big Wild Goose Pagoda tourist area. The towers are pretty simple, but they look nice (and you have to pass them to get to the good stuff)
It's good place to view in the night. More active place for photography

Westerners must be prepared to bargain at stalls in the nearby Muslim Quarter.  Begin at the Bell Tower and head southeast. The refraction over my kids' heads, in our Bell Tower photo, is from aerosol geoengineering NOT moisture.

Historical construction well preserved and maintained.
Note - the exhibits inside are not originally from this building, and will be changed periodically.

reviews.text: The name can be confusing. It is a beautifully manicured garden or park, with lakes, pavilions, bridges, and a palace holding nightly performance.  It is very photogenic and one can easily spend a few hours relaxing there.

The Tang Paradise Theme Park is characterized by its portrayal of the prosperous Tang Dynasty, harmoniously blending Tang-style buildings, gardens and unparalleled cultural arts. Its layout is based on the design of the original royal garden of the Tang Dynasty. Highly recommend the outdoor live show🤩❤️
beautiful scenes everywhere you walk especially at night time.

Perhaps it’s a tourist trap but it would be a pretty well done tourist trap. It does a pretty good job of recreating ancient historical sites and the entire place lights up at night with absolutely beautiful lights. It’s a 5A tourist attraction in china which means china regards this as one of the highest graded attractions in the country. Someone of something clearly spent a lot of money to make this a worthy place to visit.
It’s a lovely area for a walk, but there is not a lot to see and it’s quite repetitive. Not worth the entry fee of 120 yuan. Highlight was feeding the goldfish and watching the swans.

data.formatted_address: Xincheng, Xi'An, China, 710003
data.name: Fortifications of Xi'an

reviews.text: The most famous city wall in China. Very well preserved and well maintained. The view here is fantastic. Toilets here are clean and is available every couple hundred meters. Love the visit and it’s unforgettable.

The Xi'an City Wall stands tall and proud, a magnificent testament to ancient Chinese architectural prowess and the city's rich history. My experience walking atop this well-preserved fortification was nothing short of awe-inspiring.

The sheer grandeur of the wall, spanning around the city like a protective embrace, is a sight to behold. The meticulous preservation allows visitors to step back in time and imagine the city's past glory. Walking or cycling along its broad paths offered panoramic views of the surrounding cityscape and the contrast between modernity and antiquity.

The attention to detail in the construction is remarkable. The watchtowers, battlements, and gates showcase the precision and skill of ancient artisans. The history embedded within every brick, every carved stone, creates an immersive experience, offering a glimpse into Xi'an's storied past.

Capturing the essence of this ancient marvel was a highlight of my visit. The sweeping views from the wall, the play of light on the aged bricks, and the architectural details provided endless opportunities for stunning photography. For those wishing to bring a piece of this historical wonder home, I highly recommend exploring the captivating photos available for purchase on www.Renes-Photo.Shop. These images beautifully encapsulate the majesty of the Xi'an City Wall, allowing you to relive its grandeur at any time.

The Xi'an City Wall isn't just a monument; it's a living testament to China's enduring legacy. It's a must-visit for history enthusiasts, offering a profound sense of connection to the past and a chance to appreciate the architectural marvels of ancient China.

A visit to the Xi'an City Wall promises a memorable journey through time, offering both a sense of grandeur and a deep appreciation for the historical significance of this magnificent structure. It's an experience that leaves an indelible mark and a lasting admiration for the ingenuity of the past.
view is fantastic on the wall. you can choose to walk or bike it.

This was my trip plan
1. Terracotta Worries and Horses Museum
2. Datang Everbright City
3. Great Wild Goose Pagoda
4. Muslim Quarter
5. Fortification of Xian
6. Bell Tower of Xian
7. Drum Tower
8.Mount Huashan

Entrance fee CNY54, bought on the spot via Wechat and entered via the South entrance, which is where the metro exit D1 leads to.

At level 2 of the city wall, there's a centerpiece of the entire area and a staff comes by at designated times to give a brief of it. Lucky to catch the 4pm one and got a better understanding of how the city wall came to be and possibly the origin of the term '买东西' , stemming from the only 2 markets at that time 东市 (local market)＆ 西市 (international one where they traded with 西域).

The entire wall is 6km long but I've clocked enough steps for the day, so I walked for just a stretch along the city wall, entering from 永宁门 and exited thru 文昌门.

data.formatted_address: 7X23+R48, Shun Cheng Xiang, 钟楼商圈 Bei Lin Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710001
data.name: Xi'an City Wall Wen Chang Gate

reviews.text:
Walk on a part of history when you visit this place. The magnificient city walls is a must visit for anyone visiting Xi'an. Entry to the city wall is free, but you need to pay if you wish to go up the walls and visit the towers. The best way to explore the walls is to rent a bike and you can cycle around it. Please be reminded that it is quite a distance to complete full cycle. But u may choose to cycle from west gate to south gate to catch the sunset. Bicycle rental is available once you get to the top of the wall (from west or south gate)
Once on top, you can get a bird's eye view of the city within the walls. Worth going and renting a bike. Ride on the path that are bumpy and made of cobblestone dated thousands of years back. Nice experience.

Next visit was to the Xian City Wall, what a beautiful walk this was!! we were impressed by the preservation of this marvellous 14 km fortification as we walked thought its “romantic” setting of red and grey colours that nearly took me back in time. Lamps and several other decorations completed a perfect setting for our quick afternoon walk admiring the hectic pace of Xian from the wall. The pathways are quite wide, so were told that it is common to see locals and tourist enjoying a bike ride through the top area, at this point, I wanted to grab a bike and go for it!!!, but we didn’t have enough time. We only did a little stroll around the wall and then we continued to the Muslim Quarter.
A remarkable view of Xi An city, a wonderful place to visit and learn more about Xi An’s history and rich culture. You can hire bike to ride along the wall.
A brilliant area to walk around do not miss walking or even biking around the wall. Take plenty of fluids and food with you as you can spend hours on the wall. Not recommended in the peak of heat.

Bike or walk atop this rebuilt city wall.  It forms a square around the old city center.  The Xian City Wall is tall and paved with stones.  It's wide enough for two lanes but cars are not allowed.  You truly feel that you've gone back centuries in time.  This is a unique urban experience.

reviews.text: Great experience for us to see such an ancient structure smack in the middle of the modern city. We went during the day and got inside relatively quickly. We decided to enter through the main wall gate which you had to take a quick walking underpass to access. Really cool spots at the top of the structure where you can see the rest of the city as well as other parts of the wall. Our family enjoyed this very much!
Lovely spot to have a walk or where to rent bikes. The total path is 14km, suggestive and impressive in some areas. By renting a bike it’s possible to complete the walk tour in less than 3 hours.

There was little I could add than what had already been said by other reviewers.  To my mind, it is  even more impressive than the Great Wall in a different way.  To see the wall that was about the height and width of our 5 storey apartment block, where they could run a dozen horses abreast on the top for miles, was mind-blowing.  I was told it would take about 4 hours to walk a full circle, which I did not do in the 34°C heat.

We visited almost the end of February and went to the area couple times also went up to the wall couple … very pleasant to be here … not just historical place and worth to visit but also very interesting & beautiful too!
Great place to do some exercise. Hire a bike at many of the locations. Please don’t forget your passport, you need it to purchase a ticket. About 56rmb

reviews.text:
I came here on a Saturday morning after failing to get admission to Shaanxi history museum which requires a reservation few days in advance. Admission is free here. This museum gives a good overview of the history of Xi'an but artefacts are less impressive.

The museum grounds are also nice and shady with a small goose pagoda, and seem much less crowded than the other museum.

If you have to choose between the Shaanxi history museum and the Xi'an museum, the Shaanxi history museum is definitely better. You get admission to see the small goose pagoda and some other buildings with the admission to the park/Xi'an museum. There are not too many exhibits in this museum. The basement has the best stuff.
A very nice museum there is a big queue to get in which takes a while to move but once your in it is well worth the wait. It has some Terracotta army statues in it. this is a must see in Xian.
a must visit place , both Museum and the pagoda tower presented a history  of Han and Tang dynasty Culture and details of living with amazing structure of the pagoda.

If you have already visited the Shaanxi Musuem or are planning to visit it during your trip to Xi'an, you could skip this one. It is a small museum accompanying the Small Pagoda and doesn't have a variety and diverse items and relics as those in the Shaanxi Museum.

reviews.text: This was my third visit. The first two times were before the days of digital cameras !!!  It is absolutely amazing what they had done to protect such ancient treasure and to develop the surrounding area into a must visit destination for Xian.  It opens at 8 am, do go early to enjoy the peace of the Pagoda and its surroundings Monastery.
Amazing cultural relic that is open for the public. Literally a day and night difference in view and athmosphere on the street in Xi'An center.
大雁塔，da yan ta, very stunning at night, a lot of young people here, dress up like Tang dynasty pretty lady. Don’t miss out the water fountain show as well.

Beautiful place with lots of people around throughout the day. Lots of street vendors, photoshoots, food, and shopping going on around the plaza. Datang everbright city is also within walking distance and a must do if in the area. Clean public restrooms available!

One of the landmark buildings in Xi'an. It was built in c. 648 – c. 649 during the Tang dynasty and originally had five stories. It was rebuilt in 704 during the reign of Empress Wu Zetian and its exterior brick façade was renovated during the Ming dynasty.

According to wiki, "One of the pagoda's many functions was to hold sutras and figurines of Gautama Buddha that were brought to China from India by the seventh-century Buddhist monk, scholar, traveller, and translator Xuanzang. Today, the interior walls of the pagoda feature engraved statues of Buddha by the renowned 7th-century artist Yan Liben."

So there is quite a lot of history, Buddhism and literature related to it, the most famous of which is "Journey to the west" for average Chinese.

data.formatted_address: 72 You Yi Xi Lu, Bei Lin Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710064
data.name: Small Wild Goose Pagoda

reviews.text:
One of the popular tourist destinations in Xi'an. It shows the history of how the Buddhism spread into China during the Tang dynasty. The Pagoda structure in itself is not anything spectacular to view however the park in which the Pagoda is located is beautiful and serene. Such a calm place with some trees as old as around 800 years. Good place for a relaxed time.
Pro tip: No entry charges. Get free entry by showing your ID cards (passport for foreign nationals and Chinese ID for Chinese nationals). The ticket includes the entry to the Xi'an museum. Don't buy the music show tickets. Not that recommended.
Historic Pagoda surrounded by beautiful gardens, a great place to taking photos.

The Small Wild Goose Pagoda is one of the must see heritage sites for visitors to Xian.
It was built between the years 707 and 709 AD during the reign of Emperor Zhongzong 唐中宗.
The pagoda was designed to store precious Buddhist scriptures brought back to China from far away India, where Buddhism was born.
Originally standing at 45 meters, the brick-built pagoda was shortened by a couple of meters after it was damaged in an earthquake in 1556.
Not long ago, visitors were still allowed to scale its internal stairs and climb to the top of the 15 level pagoda. Then came the day when the condition of the pagoda deteriorated to the point when it had to be closed to the public over safety concern.
My friends and I visited the pagoda on a day of dark clouds and a light drizzle. We reached its bottom after walking through a nice garden filled with assorted flowering trees like the cherry blossom.
My friends didn’t find anything impressive with the pagoda and continued on after just a minute.
Equipped with a camera with a telephoto lens, I was able to take a much closer look of the pagoda.
With simple lines and a lack of intricacy, the Pagoda may look simple and unimpressive. However, when I reminded myself that this is a structure which was built 1410 years ago and has survived since then, the pagoda immediately earned a marked significance on its own right. The Small Wild Goose Pagoda has played an integral role in Chinese history, especially the part it played in the development and spread of Buddhism in China.

Went there about 6 years ago on a school trip and it was very lovely! It's peaceful and beautiful, and the shop owners around the area were nice. I'd definitely suggest checking it out if you're in XiAn. (attached is a photo I took there in the spring)
Beautiful place and a very nice park.Very historical place ;peaceful;like going back in time.Entrance is free for tourists :just show your passport.Also must visit the museum:so nice!!!!

reviews.text:
One of the most historic and beautiful museums I have ever set foot on in my life. The exterior and interior are equally beautiful, both showing the great historical culture of Xi-an and Chinese history. There are two floors and many rooms in the museum to store these delicate artifacts in the museum, each of these artifacts is magnificent, vibrating an ancient aroma that can bring the visitors to Ancient China, seeing how they lived and what they used back then. Through this museum, you can as if retrieve your footsteps and view the development of China and see its history with your own eyes, immensely increasing your own historical knowledge about the place.

What a beautiful museum! Also the sensation of just seeing the photos online in comparison to seeing them in person are completely different.

It is a great museum charting the history of Xi'An.
Lots to see and it is free to enter if you are lucky enough to get one of the 12000 tickets issued every day. I have only rated 3 stars for the following reasons:
The wait in line is around 1 and a half hours, if you get there early, if you arrive later in the day it can be much longer.
The temperature in Xi'An is around 38 degrees c in the afternoon and it is not until you get closer to the museum entrance that some shade is provided, so bear that in mind when you visit.
The museum was severely overcrowded, and this unfortunately spoilt the experience as viewing the displays was very difficult due to the sheer amount of people in the museum.
There was a lot of pushing and shoving due to the lack of space around the exhibits.
The museum staff were friendly and helpful.
A nice museum with lots of antiques and cultural relics from the ancient days.. great place to learn the historical culture..

You have to pre book ticket, and you should chose the earliest time, I dont know if they clean everyday but I go on Tuesday 12h30 and the glass is like full of fingerprints you can hardly see thing anymore
And they are not foreigners friendly you can not have ticket if you are just go to the ticket counter and book it sucks
The exhibition is ok

Brilliant museum but the queue to get in where out of control took almost 2 hours. Wouldn't recommend in the peak of heat or if you can try book tickets. Otherwise this museum is brilliant and well worth going.

data.formatted_address: 15 San Xue Jie, Bei Lin Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710001
data.name: 西安碑林

reviews.text:
As the name of this place indicates, it is a museum of historical gravestones in China.

The entry ticket is inexpensive as part of the museum was not open due to renovation work in progress. Just be mindful this museum is deeply involved with Chinese history and calligraphy. Even for people growing up in China, going there without a professional guide can be hard, as you won't get much by just looking at the displays themselves.

Highly recommend visiting by attending a tour if you are interested in Chinese history and calligraphy.
Some of china’s most important histories are carved on stones, this site is a collection of these artefacts, definitely worth visiting. However it might be a bit difficult to find English guide.
Sadly it is under renovation so most steles, including the Nestorian stele aren’t available to view. I was told it will reopen next year. Current entrance fee is 10RMB.

Stele Forest, is a pretty unique museum for steles and stone sculptures. To appreciate the artifacts in the museum, you probably need to know one or two things about the traditional Chinese calligraphy, which is a big part of Chinese culture.

Cool spot to visit, but I would definitely recommend going with a tour guide or someone who's knowledgeable about the subject.  I don't recall there being any English there, or many explanatory plaques/signs in any language.  This was a few years back, though, so it could have changed. The inscription stones are pretty neat in any case.

data.formatted_address: China, Shan Xi Sheng, Xi An Shi, Bei Lin Qu, 钟楼商圈南门环岛7W2W+RQ2 邮政编码: 710068
data.name: Xi'an Wall Yongningmen （North Gate）

reviews.text:
The Xi'an City Wall has many gates. There are passages up and down the city wall near many gates, so there is no need to enter and exit at the same gate. The most famous are the four facing doors:

The South Gate (Yongning Gate) is the best-restored gate. It is also the gate most commonly used by tourists to climb the city wall, and it is also the gate that has been open the longest. The underground passage of Yongningmen Station on Metro Line 2 can directly lead to Yongningmen, and there is also the Forest of Steles Museum nearby. Personally, I recommend climbing to the wall from this door.

In addition to the south gate, you can also climb the wall from the east gate (Changle Gate), west gate (Anding Gate), north gate (Anyuan Gate) and some other city gates.

Once you get on the Yongning Gate and walk to the left, there is a bicycle rental place.  You can rent a bicycle for a single person or go for tandem for two people.

Apart from the rental fee, you have to put down a 100¥ deposit, which will be refunded at the return of the bicycle.

Riding along the whole circle will be 13.74 km and can take 1.5 and 2.5 hours depending how much activities you will do in the ride, such as stopping to take photos and going down the wall etc.

Riding on the city wall of 1400 years history is one of the coolest things in all my travels.

one of the most iconic tourist attractions in xi’an. had to to pay for the entrance ticket to enter. very long walking about 7,000 steps for the whole route but worth it. there were bicycles for rent available. not recommended for elderly but nice for younger ones.
It is pretty nice to either take a stroll or a bike ride on the Xi’an Wall evening time, enjoying the scenery of the city.

This is the best gate of all at the Xi'an wall. The really beauty of this gate comes out at night. It is a must visit at night. I would say this is the nightlife of Xi'an. The gate is spectacularly lit up with different light colors at night and it just looks magnificent. A stroll from this gate to the bell tower at night is highly recommended. Do not miss this!

Very cool tourist attraction.  Great place to go up and really try to feel the history, imagine what it would have been like a thousand or two years ago.  Also a good spot to exercise!  A lot of people like to rent bikes and ride all the way around, and we would have liked to do that, too, but we went in late July, and it was just brutally hot--I think we would have sweated ourselves to death.  Maybe next time!

Beautiful place. Authentic architecture...

There may have been 200 different species of tulips and 200 brides getting their photographs taken.  Wedding photography appears to be big business at garden.  The tulips were beautiful and well cared for, however they were lacking identification tags.  In spite of the wonderful care, I found Chinese people appear to have little respect for plants and many were stepped on.   As an American touring China, I found Chinese people would destroy the flowers to pose for a photo.  I found this distasteful.  Would have liked to have seen some platyceriums common in SE Asia but it probably gets too cold in Xi'an.  The gardens are beautiful, however the variety of plants are limited, mostly tulips.

data.name: Yongxingfang

reviews.text: Great place to get some food in the evening. There are dozens of different stalls that sell a single dish for ~¥10-15. Vegetarian options as well. Also some small restaurants and various arts & crafts shops. Nice vibe and very colorful place.

As the moon rises above the ancient city of Xi'an, the air fills with whispers of a bygone era. The YongXingFang Square, once the esteemed residence of Prime Minister Wei Zhang during the illustrious reign of Emperor Taizong, beckons travelers into its timeless embrace. I, along with three friends from Yemen, ventured into this historic enclave at 10 PM, drawn by the allure of its storied past and the serene beauty of its nighttime aura.

The square's soft lantern glow gave off the impression that you were entering a set where every stone and beam had a story to tell. As we wandered through the expansive grounds, the night added a layer of mystique to the ancient structures. The play of light and shadow danced across the ornate carvings and sturdy columns, each architectural detail a testament to the grandeur of the Tang Dynasty.

Capturing the essence of Yongxingfang Square at night was a photographer’s delight. The interplay of shadows and light cast dramatic patterns across the structures, each snapshot a testament to the enduring beauty of Tang architectural prowess. Our photographs did more than just document; they captured the soul of the square, each frame a narrative woven with elements of ancient grandeur.

Spending an hour in Yongxingfang Square felt all too brief, yet deeply enriching. It was as though time had slowed, allowing us to savor each moment amidst the echoes of history. The experience was a profound reminder of Xi'an’s rich cultural tapestry and the enduring legacy of the Tang Dynasty.
Interesting place day & night for food and art&craft accessories etcs.. Very big market place, which is always very crowded.
By far my favorite mimic ancient lifestyle nightmarket place. You can find whatever that is in your mind and have it in a way that resembles to people living in a thousand years ago.
many kind of restaurants with unique specialty. mostly only accept wechat pay

data.formatted_address: 30 Hua Jue Xiang, 北院门小吃一条街 Lian Hu Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710007
data.name: 清真大寺

reviews.text: The Great Mosque of Xi'an is easy to miss as you walk down back alleys and past souvenir and food stands. But if you are able to find the small and inconspicuous entrance and pay the 25 kuai ($3.50) admission fee, you will be glad you did. Located smack in the middle of the Muslim Quarter (which in turn is located smack in the middle of a city of 12 million people), it is amazing how calm, serene, and peaceful this place is. It is full of beautiful buildings, trees, fountains and landscapes are covered in colorful prayer flags. It is especially cool around prayer time, when locals come strolling in, chatting to each other and smiling on their way to the prayer hall. Not even remotely touristy, this is a very worthwhile sight to see, and a great contrast to the hustle, bustle and noise you will encounter at the shops, stands and markets of the surrounding Muslim Quarter

This is a must see place in Xian. It is one of the best preserved historical sites in China. The mosque is still in use and well managed. No smoking and few tourists. Give you some sense of Hui culture and traditions.

Bring your camera. This is an incredible street, with merchants on both sides ready to dazzle tourists. These aren't merchants who are begging -- they have a constant stream of customers coming to them and are probably some of the richest merchants in Xian!

So many incredible food options to try, even as a vegan.

Absolutely worth checking out.
Such a peaceful place
Great visit highly recommended.

You will see chinese people exercising, group stretching , synchronized dancing, etc. Majority are senior citizens. Very active people.  Like it. Place is well maintaned. Even the sides of the wall are clean. care takers are very visible; sweeping the road and alleys. Gifts shops and souvenir stores are  available and numerous. You can also bargain. Got several souvenirs at super bargain prices compared to stalls located at major tourist areas. Will come back to walk the whole stretch of the wall.
If you have time, go ride a bike on the Xi'an city wall. Great sight, nice people and some Cafés.
Wish we had the opportunity to stay for the show, but really great seeing it at night with the lights!

wall refurbished during the ming dynasty, a must visit place if one is visiting xi'an. view of the city from the top is awesome especially with the setting sun. bicycle on rental are available and there are plenty of food stalls and eateries too.
The city wall is a great attraction. Laid back and varied. The main entrance gets crowded at night when the lights come on.

Taste: cold noodles, octopus balls, fresh grilled squid skewers

You can get to Xi'an great mosque, drum tower and bell tower from here.
The street is crowded at night, beware of pickpocket.
My favourite place in all of Xi'an! The food is amazing and it's so fun to explore the streets and restaurants.

There are tons of Muslim noodle shops in town that are just as good and no tourist groups to mob the place. A local I met on the train here told me to avoid it and he was right. There was a great noodle shop near the convention center with the same noodles and pao muo style noodle bits. There is a super old mosque behind the market street. There used to be some artisans here doing sniffer bottle arts and the like but it is all overrun with paper cuts and low quality tourist kitsch.

reviews.text:
6000 years ago... banpo village ruled by women.  Quiet place. Not so many tourists. Very dusty.
If you want to see actual village, skeletons, burial sites, earthen wears, etc. May finish in an hour or so.not as famous as the other  sites in china.  Worth to see past culture.

Worth visiting if you have already hit up the other big tourist attractions in the area. They have excavated a village from 6000 years ago. Lots of earthen jars used to bury children. The outside activities were all closed when we went (January).

Close to Subway Line 1 - Banpo Station (Exit A) If you have the time, this is an interesting place to vist. 6000 year old relics & remnants of a civilization is something you don't see every day. Original excavation sites makes this visit interesting. This place doesn't have the grander of the Terracotta Warriors, But it is fascinating in its own realm.  Surrounding tall buildings makes you wonder (Whiskey Tango Foxtrot) the city planners were thinking when they allowed all the construction- makes you wonder how much history was destroyed. Not crowded during the visit; 55CNY entrance fee in October 2019.
Absolute gem. Tells you a lot about how the Neanderthals in Xi’an 6000 years ago lived and built their houses. It is also very accessible by the nearby Banpo metro station.
A very historial place on human civilization 6000yrs history;recreated in details.worth a visit

reviews.text: Thats most amazing place to be familiar with Chinese culture and its development progress. It needs at least three hours to enjoy it that couldn't be possible in a  tour visit.
So so no English anything

Although the scale is small, it contains national treasure-level cultural relics, including the earliest bronzes of the Western Zhou Dynasty, the only relic recording King Wu's defeat of Zhou, as well as the gold coffin and silver statue unearthed from the ruins of Qingshan Temple in Tang Dynasty, and the Sakyamuni Tathagata relic treasure tent (which is extremely rare). Precious Buddhist cultural relics), these cultural relics have been listed as national special cultural relics. The museum contains the relics of Sakyamuni Tathagata, which are the remains of the Buddha. It is really a must-see.
Everything is so perfect that I feel like taking it all home.

It is a fantastic place, of incredible dimensions, thousands of warriors created in terracotta, soldiers, chariots, horses that were discovered by chance thanks to a farmer who was working his land. Today he signs the souvenir books for the thousands of tourists who visit them. Essential.

data.formatted_address: Chang'An, Xi'An, China, 710111
data.name: Xi'an Qinling Wildlife Park

reviews.text:
I had an incredible day with my friends at Qingling Wildlife Park in Xi'an. The park is expansive, so I would recommend arriving early in the morning to make the most of your time there. The journey from Xi'an takes around two hours, but it is definitely worth it. Admission tickets cost 140 RMB for adults and 100 RMB for students.

Once you enter the park, you can take amazing photos and explore the different areas. There is a gate for the games park, and another road that leads to the buses which take you to the open wildlife park. The bus ride lasts around 30-40 minutes, during which you can see incredible wild animals roaming freely in their natural habitats. Although the bus doesn't stop at any specific location, I recommend recording the wildlife trip on your phone or camera to preserve this unforgettable experience.

After the wildlife trip, the bus drops you off at the park, where you can spend the rest of the day walking, eating, taking photos, and playing games. It's the perfect opportunity to unwind and enjoy the beautiful scenery. Overall, I highly recommend visiting Qingling Wildlife Park for an unforgettable day out in nature.

Qingling Wildlife Park is home to a wide variety of animals, including but not limited to Siberian tigers, lions, giraffes, elephants, and pandas. It's an incredible opportunity to see these animals up close and in person. The park is beautifully designed and maintained, with plenty of greenery and picturesque landscapes. It's a great place to relax and escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. In addition to the wildlife park, there are also other attractions such as a water park, a roller coaster, and a 5D cinema. There's truly something for everyone at Qingling Wildlife Park.

If you're interested in learning more about the animals, there are educational exhibits and presentations throughout the park. You can learn about their habitats, behaviors, and conservation efforts. The park is also committed to environmental sustainability. They use solar energy to power some of their facilities, and have implemented waste reduction and recycling programs. The park staff are friendly and helpful, and there are plenty of amenities such as food stalls, restrooms, and seating areas throughout the park.
Great Zoo, very famous for white Panda.
You can feed the beasts with meat that staff give to you, which is so fun!
i dont want 2 go again

The closest station is Weiqu South Station, which is the last stop on Metro Line 2, but it is far from the zoo, so take bus number 334 and get off at the 24th stop, Wildlife Park Station, which is about a 10-minute walk.
The location is inconvenient if you don't have a car.

reviews.text: It's always nice to come back and see the city from the old walls. Even riding the bike or just walking on it. There are also some small souvenir stores, ice cream, tea, or coffee stores. Toilet as well. It's a nice window to ancient China through the old architecture that remains after many demolitions from the last century during the Cultural Revolution. Thank you🤩

Venturing into the heart of Xi'an, the Changle Gate atop the city wall stands as a majestic testament to the rich history that echoes through its ancient stones. A prominent landmark, this gate beckons travelers into a realm where the past seamlessly intertwines with the present.

As I approached the Changle Gate, the sheer grandeur of its architectural marvel unfolded before my eyes. The imposing structure, part of the formidable city wall, exuded an aura of historical significance, inviting me to embark on a journey through time.

Upon entry, a nominal fee granted access to a world steeped in history and cultural heritage. The panoramic view from the gate unveiled the city's landscape, a harmonious blend of modernity and ancient charm. The fee seemed a small price to pay for the privilege of witnessing such a breathtaking spectacle.

For those with an adventurous spirit and ample time, the option to rent a bicycle presented itself as an enticing opportunity. Riding atop the city wall, encircling the ancient heart of Xi'an, offered a unique perspective—one that transcended the conventional tourist experience.

The ambiance surrounding Changle Gate resonated with a sense of tranquility, providing a welcome escape from the hustle and bustle of urban life. It became a sanctuary where history whispered through the wind, and every stone exuded tales of bygone eras.

In the company of fellow explorers, the Changle Gate experience evolved into a shared appreciation for the city's legacy. Conversations ebbed and flowed against the backdrop of the cityscape, creating cherished memories that mirrored the timeless allure of Xi'an.

Beautiful view of preserved gate ay night.
As we didn’t rent any bike, we could only manage to walk here from the South Gate (Yongningmen), which about 3km.
One should start touring on the wall around 4-5pm so you could experience and see the amazing views of inside and outside of the wall in the daylight, and also during the night when all the lights and lanterns turned on.
But for me the most spectacular view cames during the blue hours.

This is one of the major gates along the Xian City Wall. It is popular with tourists and offer many sights. Fee is required to enter and the view is fantastic. There is bicycles for rental if you have the time to cycle around the wall.

One of the four main gates of the Xi'an city wall (and one of the places you can rent a bike), it is large and impressive. Started out bike trip around the wall from this gate and thoroughly enjoyed it

data.name: Guanzhong Folk-custom Art Museum

reviews.text:
Visiting the Xi'an Guanzhong Folk Custom Art Museum in Zhongnanshan Mountain was a fascinating cultural journey. I went with three Yemeni friends and a Chinese friend, who drove us in his camping car. We spent four hours exploring this open-air museum, designed to look like a traditional village.

Walking through the cobbled streets and wooden buildings, we felt like we were stepping back in time. The museum showcased traditional houses, folk art, and crafts, giving us a glimpse into local history and culture. Our Chinese friend shared insights that made the exhibits more meaningful, helping us understand the traditional customs on display.

The live performances of local opera and music added to the experience, creating a lively atmosphere. The artisans and staff were welcoming, sharing stories about their work and the local traditions.

It is a private museum. It is said that the owner of the museum collected stone carvings, doors, windows, canopies, etc. from old buildings from various places and rebuilt them. I personally think it is interesting, and the sincerity is also admirable.
There is also the Shaanxi old tune performance that has been awarded the intangible world cultural heritage. It is said to be the rock music of Shaanxi 😁
It's very exquisite, and I can learn a lot about the folk architecture of ancient Guanzhong.
A very worthwhile place to visit!

data.name: Shaanxi Art Museum

reviews.text:
Wonderful art musuem. Set over 5 floors, this open plan art space is a real joy. The exhibits also change every few weeks which keeps it fresh. It doesn't get very busy which gives you ample time and space to enjoy the art work.

It is very easy to find and the tickets are free. However you can not take water inside.
Stop by occasionally, lots of excellent works

Not bad for learning about Chinese history in general. But the truth is that it is something short. We expected it better because of how it was painted to us. Even so, you should go if you like the ancient pieces that have constituted the future of our current humanity. If you go in the afternoon there are fewer people and it is quieter, but not too late as they close early.

Remarkable circular architecture. It is worth it if you want to capture where today's mural or broad Chinese painting is going: abrupt landscapes of one or two colors, images distorted by thick strokes, natural transparencies, sometimes current motifs, very peculiar perspectives, etc. Quite curious.
A good museum, I recommend visiting it

reviews.text:
Waste of time. Bad lighting. Crowds. Hot. Far away. Useless website, unable to buy tickets without a chinese phone number. No explanations. Dirty toilets without toilet paper. Intrusive guides. Long walk from entrance.

Good and long food street though.

One of the worse experiences ever. When you arrive and you see around 500 buses parked outside because inside the parking is full it is not a good signal. Long queues to get in, not better. The room was so packed that advancing a single step could take more than ten seconds. Meanwhile dozens of people pushing from behind to get into the same room. Any medical emergency and you are dead. A fire, hundreds of deads. A room without proper ventilation. Kids getting squeezed. No respected time slots. In the end I didn't see any terracotta warrior. Zero. Is there any limit on the amount of tickets they can sell? Does the experience matter at all? Just don't go in summer and good luck for the rest of the year.
amazing to see such history. although there are lots of people and it is very hot depending on what time of the year you go
Very impressive! They also offer English explanations.

COME RIGHT AS IT OPENS. Get tickets before hand during the peak season. We went during December which is off peak. We arrived right as the ticket booth opened and there was no line. We contracted a guide (in Chinese) based on age. I have a theory that the older the guide is, the better the information which I know doesn't hold true in every case but you've got to go off of some sort of criteria as you pick random site guides.

Our guide turned out to be a 20 year employee of the museum so that worked out well.

There was very few people around during this time. Whatever you do, DO NOT arrive around 10am. You'll only be able to get pictures of the back of people's heads trying to take pictures of the warriors. Really 3 hours is the max and you've exhausted all the information. The exit is ridiculous though. Just wait till you see the commercialization!

data.formatted_address: Huashan Mountain, Zhouzhi County, Xi'An, China, 710409
data.name: Huashan Mountain

reviews.text: Freezing but beautiful! Make sure that you contact Jenny for your travel needs. :-)

Visibility was poor when we reached there and almost all attractions were closed. Paid almost up to USD90+ each person overall for cable car, entry park fee and bus ride. Rude and unhelpful staffs and overly pushy sales staffs who will offer to take photo of you and sell to you.
went to north peak by cable car aiming to go down at west peak (said to be most beautiful) but it closed...

I took the speed train from Xian north railway station (you can get there by metro and I recommend you to take the first one), there you can buy a ticket for around 50 rmb. The trip will take 40 minutes more or less. Once you get there get out and find the green bus. It's for free and avoid all the people that want to take you paying them money. The free bus is outside on the right walking a bit further (just follow the people).

The bus will leave you close to the entrance. There I recommend you to go from the west peak to the north (its less tiresome since it's downstairs) I did the opposite and climbed from the bottom it took me 9 hours in total to do everything so we were very tired cause it was all the time upstairs. If you do what I recommend it will be just 3-4 hours.

At the ticket office buy the ticket entrance and the bus ride to the west peak. When you get there you'll see the cable car and you line up to buy the ticket. Once you are up there just follow the maps.

You go around seeing all the peaks making a circle till you get to north peak. Get down using the cable car or walking if you want. To get back just do the same you did to get there.
The sky path is between south and west peaks. It wasn't that scary because it feels save. There were even kids doing it but it takes around two hours. One hour waiting in the line and one hour doing it (it's just 50 meters but people are slow and since it's both ways we need to stop several times and be careful).

Regarding the plank trail:

It was a nice experience and the hype of the mountain. The ticket fee is 30 rmb and if they take a picture of you they ask for 50 rmb more.

This area is located between the south and west peak.

The line to get to the beginning is about one hour and then you spend one more hour there.

It's a bit slow since there are people going both ways and taking pictures and it's breath taking at the beginning!!
Wrong coordinate, Hashan mountain is not located here but eastern Shaanxi province

data.formatted_address: Zhongnan Shan, Chang'An, Xi'An, China, 710105
data.name: Zhongnan Shan

reviews.text:
Zhongnanshan Nanwutai Mountain is famous in Xi'an for being the place where the renowned Chinese philosopher, Confucius, spent time in meditation and prayer. The mountain is also known for its scenic beauty, and is a popular tourist destination.

Today I climbed the mountain with my friends, it's 1.5 hour away from the city, mostly you need to take bus number 730 to reach the mountain destination, ticket cost 40 yuan, there is also discount 50% for students with ID Card, you will also need to pay 40 yuan for the car which will take you to the starting point which is 7-10 km away, so it's better to get a car.

After reaching the starting point, you will start climbing stairs till you reach the top, from time to time you will find resting chairs, food and drinks shops, toilets.

It's better to come prepared with heavy clothes, good shoes, gloves, water and energy bars.

There are 2 peaks on that mountain, after reaching the first peak, climb down a little bit then you will find another detour to take you to the other peak.

After reaching the top peaks, you will see amazing views from the top, so take your time to memorize these moments with photos and videos.

The starting point of the story of The Legend of the Condor Heroes
Tomb of the Living Dead
Quanzhen Sect
All in Zhongnan Mountain
Legend has it that this is the place where Zhongli of the Han Dynasty ascended to immortality, and there were many practitioners there. I don’t know whether it is true or not.

reviews.text: On earth and in heaven, songs are dancing and whirling, and the colors are equally divided. reviews.text:
HuaShan, one of the five mountains of China, is an excellent place I would say to visit or to challenge yourself. There are two options for climbing this significant mountain, either going on a cable car to halfway or climbing the whole mountain by yourself. For those inactive, I highly recommend the first option as it allows you to witness the astonishing view of mountains and valleys whilst reducing how much you walk. I barely do sport but when I chose the first option, I was able to climb to the top without breaking a sweat. I recommend climbing two steps at a time as it is easier. The higher you climb, the more beautiful and astonishing the view. The upper view of nature's creation through the mist is a delightful experience. The delicate wind that breezes on my skin creates a clear contrast to when I am on the ground. Not just the aesthetics of the mountain is amazing, the smell is also so special, the smell of nature.

You will not have to worry about hunger or toilet issues when climbing on the mountain, there are shops on top. The danger issues are limited on the mountain, as there are chains which surrounds the path, there is no possible way where you can "accidentally" slip off and fall to your death if you are being careful.

I highly recommend those to climb this magnificent mountain as the insane aesthetic bestowed by this mountain is like one of a lifetime which you would never forget. The close interaction bewen you and nature will be closer than ever, feeling as if you were mixed within it. As you looked down, the houses in the distance looked like ants, allowing you to obtain the feeling of being in control of everything you look at.

The steps on the way down may be a tiny bit steep so you may have to take your time. It took me 6 hrs to go up and down the mountain.

Remember to bring some gloves and not just one bottle of water if you decide to go here.

Highly recommend this beautiful place. This 5-star review is deserved!

Beautiful view and scenery and the crowd not too crowded .
A
Good choice to opt for north route to enjoy the scenery with partial cable car .

I had an amazing time coming here with my in-laws ! We hiked all the way up using the stairs , it took almost 6 hours ! I enjoyed every bit of it .  It was  therapeutical breathing the fresh air and watching over the amazingly shaped mountains !!
Really nice place for a good hike

Really impressive view!!! Only tours for Chinese, if you are foreign you must do it by yourself !!!! 1 hours from Xian by car. Hire a car cost around RMB800.- RT. You must go early coz you will spend all day walking the mountain....

reviews.text: It was my first time in Xi'an and my partner and I came during National Day. We wanted to go see the Terra Cotta Army, but it was fully booked because of the holiday. Instead, we came to the Big Wild Goose Pagoda. We had so much fun dressing up, walking around with others who were in their cultural outfits. Visit this location during evening hours. With the lights it is even more impressive. No really need to go inside, just experience the surroundings

I had an amazing experience here, the Pagoda is so very well preserved that you can't see that much of a difference as it was 2000 years ago, lol 😂

We had a great time and we have learned so much from this experience and we really believe Chinese culture and their architecture has always been top level.

Recommend this area of Xi'an to everyone to come and see for themselves how amazing it is.

Cheers!

Terrific historical pagoda which we visited in the evening - the whole structure is lit up at night. The whole area is full of life well into the evening, with the locals coming out to play music and dance in the public squares with fans and colourful costumes.

Pleasant complex to wander through, but take a guidebook. There are many elements and aspects that have  wonderful stories and histories, but educational signage is scant. Can be quite crowded - go early.

data.name: Daming Palace National Heritage Park

reviews.text: The heritage park is based on the ancient palace in Tang dynasty. The field is quite huge and divided into two different areas. Tourists must buy tickets to see Daming palace heritage and visit the museum inside. The charge location is about the centra of the park. The other area outside the Daming palace heritage is free, people can do all kinds of activities over there. It took me about fifteen to twenty minutes to walke from Xi’an train station to here. Then I spent half day to search the park. Obviously, I didn’t have enough time for visiting the whole spot. So prepare your energy and time to explore here.

Do not expect to see grand palaces like the Forbidden City. The site is huge, like many of the parks and scenic site in China so get the tram ride ticket with the entrance ticket. The ride around the palace ground will take  about half an hour and what you will see is landscaped greenery where all the hundreds of building are supposed to be. There are a few structure and buildings that are built to give some representation. The IMAX show next to the ticketing area will provide a better understanding and visualisation of how grand the palace was during its time. There is an area in the park where they do a miniaturised of the whole palace complex which I thought is very interesting.

The maintenance of the guide equipments in the museum was not good, the monitors shows the wrong content and incorrect operation. It will be better if the administration of the museum take care of the issue more.
The model of the ancient palace is elaborate, the sightseer can easily figure out the real scene in the ancient time.

Well for me it was such an amazing experience to come to the Heritage Park. Watch the locals during a weekday playing/singing some music or simply doing sports and other eyecatching activities (whipping trees :) ). It is indeed a long walk so make sure you take a hat or sunglasses with you, as there are large areas without trees or shade. I was there in May and had about 28 degrees. The Palace is a must see with a lot of historical facts (the silk route started here!).
The whole area was full of slums and garbage in the 90s but nowadays has reemerged as a magnificent palace. Simply awesome.

It definitely a great park for local people, but not for tourists, you cannot see any ancient building but some man-make photo-taking points. I got lost there and wasted a day there as the park is too large.  Despite the fake photos(those photos are recovery diagram of palace), we did meet some nice local there.

reviews.text:
Where is the Tomb of the Living Dead in Zhongnan Mountain?
(No one dares to enter the bottomless depths)

"Behind Zhongnan Mountain, the Tomb of the Living Dead, the Condor Heroes and the Condor Heroes disappeared from the world." This sentence comes from Yang Bing, a descendant of the Condor Heroes. So what does the Tomb of the Living Dead in Zhongnan Mountain mean? The Tomb of the Living Dead is where living people live. It is said that Wang Chongyang, the head of the Quanzhen Sect, practiced in the tomb for two years and left a Qi Jue poem to describe this cultivation method. So is the Tomb of the Living Dead real? Where is the Tomb of the Living Dead? Now we will take you to explore the unsolved mysteries about the Tomb of the Living Dead.

What does the Tomb of the Living Dead in Zhongnan Mountain mean?

In Chapter 39 of Yitian Slaying the Dragon, Yang Guo and Xiao Longnu's daughter Yang Bing appeared to help and rescued Zhang Wuji's adoptive father Xie Xun. Later, Zhang Wuji thanked her and wanted to ask her name, but she only said, "Behind Zhongnan Mountain, there is the Tomb of the Living Dead, and the Condor Heroes have disappeared from the world."

At this time, the meaning of this sentence is that I am a descendant of the Condor Heroes. At the end of "The Legend of the Condor Heroes", Yang Guo and Xiao Longnu decided to retire to the world and return to the Tomb of the Living Dead to spend the rest of their lives together.

The original meaning of this sentence is that after a living person enters the tomb of the living dead, his past self is already dead and his past self is buried. Only by abandoning everything in the past can we realize the Tao and the true meaning.

In "The Legend of the Condor Heroes", Wang Chongyang, the head of the Quanzhen sect, practiced in the Tomb of the Living Dead for two years in order to isolate himself from the world and concentrate on enlightenment. In the end, he was completely reborn in the Tomb of the Living Dead and attained enlightenment. While he was practicing, he also wrote a Qijue poem "The Tomb of the Living Dead Presents Ning Bo Gong", one of which reads like this:

The living dead are here, just because of wind, fire, earth and water. In the tomb, I took real elixir every day and exchanged a little bit of dust for my mortal body. The living dead, the living dead, death in life is a good cause, the silence in the tomb is pure and quiet, separated from the mortal world.

It can be seen that Wang Chongyang was practicing in the Tomb of the Living Dead at that time.

But someone has to ask, these are all records in novels. Is the Tomb of the Living Dead real? Does the Tomb of the Living Dead really exist? If it is the real Tomb of the Living Dead, where is it?

The Tomb of the Living Dead is so deep that no one dares to enter.

The Tomb of the Living Dead is real, it really does exist. The Tomb of the Living Dead is located in the Chengdao Palace, 40 kilometers southwest of the ancient capital of Xi'an, and 4 or 5 miles away from the Chongyang Palace. It is now located in Zu'an Town, Hu County, Xi'an City.

The four characters "Tomb of the Living Dead" are engraved on the stone tablet in front of the tomb. Experts once visited this place to investigate, and after opening the tomb passage, they found that there was indeed a basement in the Tomb of the Living Dead, exactly as described in the novel. It's just that the basement is bottomless and no one dares to go in. For safety reasons, experts feared that someone might break in without permission, so they sealed the tomb passage with soil. So far, no one has gone to the tomb to find out...

data.formatted_address: China, Shan Xi Sheng, Xi An Shi, Yan Ta Qu, 电视塔盘道88号 邮政编码: 710063
data.name: Shaanxi Nature Museum （East Gate）

reviews.text: Big Dino in front

The Shaanxi Natural History Museum is a key provincial construction project decided by the Provincial Party Committee and the Provincial Government in December 1998 and formally established in October 1999. The museum is located at No. 88, Chang'an South Road, Xi'an, covering an area of ​​103 acres, with a total construction area of ​​16,107 square meters. It is a project approved by the Provincial Planning Commission, designed by the Northwest Architectural Design Institute, and organized and implemented by the Provincial Unified Construction Office. On October 17, 2003, the 15th Provincial Governor's Office Meeting decided that on the premise that the project positioning and land use would not change, the allocation would be handed over to the Provincial Investment Group Company for operation and completion. Since then, the Provincial Investment Group Company has made additional investment and organized construction. It was opened to the public on January 5, 2008 and is responsible for operation and management.
Having a natural history museum is a symbol and necessary supporting condition of an international metropolis. Shaanxi Energy Group Co., Ltd. (formerly the Provincial Investment Group Company) shares government responsibilities, establishes science education public welfare undertakings, and builds and manages the Shaanxi Natural Museum. Through continuous development in the seven years since its opening, it has quietly shouldered a responsibility for the city of Xi'an. social responsibility.
Biological fossils from hundreds of millions of years ago have appeared here, and more than 20,000 specimens have made their home here. The Shaanxi Natural History Museum talks with history, nature and science through nearly 3.7 billion-year-old specimens to tell the story of man and nature, adding indispensable taste and rich cultural heritage to the international metropolis of Xi'an. The exhibition hall now has three halls and one courtyard: the natural exhibition hall has geological phenomena, paleontology gallery, magical Qinling Mountains, insect kingdom, and light of life exhibition hall, displaying more than 230 species of rare animal specimens such as giant pandas and crested ibises, ichthyosaurs, pterosaurs, There are paleontological fossils that are hundreds of millions of years old, such as Mamenchisaurus, turtles, and dragonflies, as well as precious plant specimens such as unifolia; the Light of Coal Sea Exhibition Hall is the only one in the province that focuses on the formation, exploration, mining, utilization, and ecological protection of coal. The exhibition hall is composed of five parts: "Gifts from Nature", "Exploring Treasures by Knocking on the Ground", "Coal Mining to Benefit the World", "Enlightening the Future" and "Using Nature"; there is a robot solving the Rubik's Cube in the science and technology corridor on the first floor of the science and technology exhibition hall. , flight experience, 3D printer and other 54 high-tech exhibition items. There is a sound and light tunnel on the second floor, a dome theater on the third floor, a low-carbon environmental protection exhibition and a brave passage on the fourth floor. The dome theater is the only one in the northwest, with 175 seats, 30 The tilted spherical shadow screen is stunning and spectacular. The museum area also has a "bird singing forest", a large paleontology display stand, a landscape fish pond, a simulated Mamenchisaurus, a Tyrannosaurus rex and other outdoor scenes. More than 100 kinds of flowers and plants are planted in the green space of the museum area.
In September 2015, 136 specimens of the world’s rare wild animals, including African lions, elephants, and giraffes, donated by international philanthropist Kenneth Eugene Bellin, were also grandly displayed.
The Shaanxi Natural History Museum is a growth partner for children and an enlightening teacher for teenagers. It is a paradise for teenagers and tourists to learn the history of natural development and get close to nature. With an average annual visitor volume of 500,000, it has become a famous tourist attraction favored by tourists from inside and outside the province who care about the natural environment and protect ecological civilization.
Opening hours: Wednesday to Sunday every week (closed on Mondays and Tuesdays), open around the clock on statutory holidays and student holidays. Open from 9am to 5pm.

data.formatted_address: 97M7+99W, Qin Ling Bei Lu, Lin Tong Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710611
data.name: Qinshihuang Diling Museum Lishanyuan

reviews.text: Get free shuttle bus from terracotta in front of statue to this place, entrance is free but recommend to pay rmb 15 for pool car drop in/off at each building

This is included in your terracotta warriors ticket and includes a free shuttle. No need to consult the taxi drivers. It's honestly a big skip if you're in a time crunch. Some people like it, some don't. If you have time to burn it's a good place for a walk.
Waste of time. Not impressive. Nice park to walk but that’s it. Entrance is far so they can scam you into buying shuttle pass. Annoying taxi drivers after exit.

Despite being the actual tomb where Qinshihuang, the greatest emperor in Chinese history, has laid rest for centuries, Lishanyuan is not frequently visited.
Many people may not even know of its existence for they may assume the terra cotta museum /mausoleum to be the place where the mighty king rests. Even for those who are aware of Lishanyuan, they may not bother as it is to them an inconspicuous mount inside an inconspicuous garden.
If you have the time, I recommend that you make this trip after you have visited the terra cottas. And I must stress here the after.
It is after you have been put in awe, not only by the scale and magnificence of the terra cottas, but also by the cacophony and shuffling of the crowds, that you wish to find peacefulness and serenity. Lishanyuan gives you exactly this contrast and relief.
You will be walking down a footpath in a garden landscaped like any ordinary garden. At the end of the path, you will see in front of you a small hill under which is supposed to be buried Qinshihuang. You will spend this moment to reload what you know of this Emperor, his dynasty, his good and bad deeds, his legacy and influence to the Chinese and Chinese culture. As you depart the grounds along the same footpath you came in, this thought may come to your mind - however great or small a person you are, you will end up the same, under a mount of dirt.

A lot of Liyuan is a just trees and patches of wild grass. So there's not as much to see. But there are burial pits on display here too (smaller but with more variety of different items).

What is quite impressive here is the mound that contains the Emperor's actual tomb. When you approach, it just looks like a small hill that couldn't possibly be manmade, but it is. Also good if you want to take a stroll.

data.formatted_address: 5XVQ+Q3G, Qu Jiang Chi Nan Lu, 曲江商圈 Yan Ta Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710061
data.name: 秦二世陵遗址公园

reviews.text:
The Qin II Mausoleum Heritage Park is located on the south side of Qujiang Pool in Qujiang New District, Xi'an City (formerly Yanta District). The heritage park is divided into two parts: the heritage area and the exhibition area. The ruins area includes the remaining buildings, the mountain gate, the main hall, and the mausoleum of Emperor Qin II Hu Hai; the exhibition area includes the tourist service center, the Qin Dynasty Exhibition Hall, and the Exhibition Hall of Unearthed Cultural Relics. The entire cemetery covers an area of ​​more than 20 acres. Free and open.
Directly south of the ruins area is a three-bay mountain gate with a red door and red pillars. Passing through the mountain gate and climbing up the stairs, you will find a hard-mountain-style hall built in the Qin Dynasty architectural style. There are a group of statues "referring to deer as horses" displayed in the hall. Colorful portraits and text introductions of Hu Hai, Zhao Gao, Ziying, Yan Le, who are more than 2 meters tall.
On the corridor leading to the main hall along the steps from the entrance gate, the representative historical dynasties of China are marked in order according to the Gregorian calendar. Taking one step will enter a dynasty, giving people the feeling of walking into a time machine and going directly from the present dynasty to the Qin Dynasty.
At the very end of the main hall is Hu Hai's mausoleum, which is made of earth and is circular. There is a stone tablet on the north side of the tomb. The six official script characters "Mausoleum of the Second Emperor of Qin" are inscribed on the stele. It was written in the 41st year of Qianlong's reign (1776 AD) by Bi Yuan, the Minister of War and deputy censor of Shaanxi Province, and by the official of Xianning County. Yin Zhi erected a monument. Because at that time, this place belonged to Xianning County, Shaanxi Province.
On August 6, 1956, Hu Hai's tomb was listed as the first batch of key cultural relics protection units by the Shaanxi Provincial People's Committee, and a monument was erected by the Xi'an Municipal People's Government.
There are green pines and cypresses around the tomb of Hu Hai, accompanied by peach trees, redbuds and ginkgo trees. Winding paths lead to secluded areas, with birds chirping and flowers fragrant. In mid-March, the peach blossoms behind the tomb and the redbuds in front of the tomb are blooming, adding a bit of liveliness to this solemn place.
However, it is doubtful whether this tomb is that of Hu Hai. Data show that in 2009, Xi'an cultural relics and archaeologists conducted archaeological exploration of the tomb and found that the tomb was a multi-chamber tomb with a long slope and brick passages. Judging from the shape of the tomb, it should be a Han Dynasty tomb.

The Qin Shang Exhibition Hall in the exhibition area takes the main historical events experienced by Qin II as the main line, and uses the rise and decline of Qin civilization as the background of the story. While displaying the civilization of the Qin Dynasty, it also shows the history of the Qin Dynasty from prosperity to decline. process. There is also an exhibition of fine cultural relics unearthed in Qujiang New District that is held year-round. However, I was in a hurry and did not visit it, which is a pity.

Personally, I think the most intriguing thing about the entire scenic spot is the four couplets on the mountain gate. I have specially excerpted it for you, the readers, to enjoy.
Under the plaque on the mausoleum of Emperor Qin II, a couplet reads:
If we fail to preserve the legacy of our late emperor’s great achievements, a handful of dirt beside the pond will only retain eternal sorrow.
Kong Gui has been an emperor and a powerful king for thousands of years. How many people have paid homage to him?

Under the plaque, a couplet reads:
This fortune may decline, this emperor may be sad. The lonely tomb in the setting sun cannot be extinguished for a long time.
Its rise and fall are also sudden. Before the clear water of Qujiang River, I ponder the ups and downs of the second generation.

Under the plaque of the Master of Funerals, the couplet reads:
The anecdotal story of one man destroying himself and having his second son die will only serve as a laughingstock for thousands of years to come.
Without benevolence and righteousness, how can one protect one's property? The desolate smoke and decaying grass remain, but the lonely grave remains and weeps at the setting sun.

Under the plaque of Kuanggu Meditation, the couplet reads:
At that time, the country was destroyed and the fragrance was remnant. Qin Gui II was not the only one who died.
On this day, the wind is clear and the moon is bright, but the lonely tomb is facing thousands of people
Yuan Tengfei once said that reading history is reading people’s hearts. History always repeats itself, often with striking similarities, because people's hearts never change. If we don't learn from the lessons of the capsized boat, then things will rise and fall, and the boat may capsize again. It is truly a source of laughter for thousands of years and a source of sadness for eternity.
Clean, no one around

data.formatted_address: 55 Xian Ning Xi Lu, Bei Lin Qu, Xi An Shi, Shan Xi Sheng, China, 710048
data.name: Xingqinggong Park

reviews.text:
Xingqinggong Park, located in the historic city of Xi'an, offers visitors a serene and picturesque retreat steeped in rich history. Originally the site of an imperial palace during the Tang Dynasty, this park beautifully combines natural beauty with cultural heritage, making it a must-visit destination.

As you enter the park, you're immediately transported away from the city's hustle and bustle into a tranquil oasis. The well-maintained paths invite you to wander and explore the diverse landscapes, from vibrant flower beds to expansive green lawns. The centerpiece of the park is a large, serene lake that reflects the sky above and the ancient-style pagodas surrounding it. It's common to see locals engaged in tai chi or families enjoying boat rides, which adds a lively yet peaceful atmosphere to the area.

Cultural activities are abundant here. Traditional Chinese music often fills the air, played by elderly locals under shaded pavilions, providing a soothing soundtrack to your visit. Children play nearby, adding bursts of laughter to the mix. For history enthusiasts, numerous plaques and statues scattered throughout the park offer insights into its imperial past, enriching your understanding of Xi'an's significant role during the Tang Dynasty.

Visiting Xingqinggong Park is not just about enjoying the natural beauty; it's an experience of connecting with the local culture and history. It’s a place where every corner offers a story, and the peaceful environment is perfect for those looking to relax and rejuvenate. Whether you are interested in the historical aspects, the natural settings, or simply a day out with family, Xingqinggong Park provides a charming and enriching environment for all visitors.

A reasonably big garden in Xian, well worth and hour or two to stroll around especially when the flowers are in bloom. I was there when the tulips are full glory. The park is well managed and it is very pleasant to wonder around.

Really  nice park in the midlle of the city. You will find people singing, dancing and doing aerobics. Small but dated amusement park in the corner with some rides for the kids and adults. Nice lake in the middle
It’s a nice park. But definitely better come in spring or summer, when there are flowers and the shops are open. Winter is ok for a walk.
One of the most beautiful parks in Xian, love it!

reviews.text: The price/quality is very good. The price is affordable and similar to that of older and more uncomfortable hotels. The quality is excellent. Rooms have a kitchenette with everything needed to cook and are very clean. You have also access to a gym and various facilities like sauna table tennis and laundary. By far the best place I have tried among the many hotels I stayed in Xian and Beijing.

Hotel is situated around a local community with parks, supermarket and restaurants nearby. Xianlinglu subway station requires some 15mins walking.

Room is spacious for couple that comes with kitchenate. Cleanliness still acceptable but require improvement at the shower. Hotel provide self service laundry. Breakfast is mainly Chinese flavour, but become dull after a few days. Overall a nice hotel
I have good impressions of my stay at this hotel. Unusual design of the rooms.
A wonderful, comfortable hotel with incredibly helpful and friendly staff. I would stay here again.
good
